Events.eventName: Building Themes: Art and Architecture at Williams
Events.Description: From the Prendergast Lectures Topics in American Art. Symposium explored the many ways in which art and architecture intersect in the context of Williams College. Two of the talks focused on architecture that houses art: the new W.L.S. Spencer Studio Art Building and Lawrence Hall, home of the Williams College Museum of Art and the Art Department. The other two talks turned the tables and showed how paintings encompass architecture: the Italian watercolors of Louis Kahn and Edward Hopper's treatment of architecture as metaphor. All four challenge the false boundaries that traditionally divide the expressive nature of art from that of architecture.

Panelists from seven academic departments and the Williams College Museum of Art addressed issues of modernism they had previously confronted in their disciplines in general and their own research in particular. The resulting dialogue drew on the study of American and European art and literature as well as religion, philosophy, and physics and was opened up to other fields, represented by other professors and curators who served as audience respondents.

Events.eventName: Charles Prendergast and the Taste for Ancient and Innocent Art in the Early 20th Century
Events.Description: The symposium was presented in conjunction with the exhibition "'Beauties... of a Quiet Kind': The Art of Charles Prendergast from the Collections of the Williams College Museum of Art and Mrs. Charles Prendergast".

The symposium was funded by the Eugenie Prendergast Foundation as part of the series "The Prendergast Lectures: Topics in American Art". Associated with exhibitions "Maurice Prendergast in Context" (September 15-November 25, 1990) and "Charles Prendergast" (September 29-December 16, 1990).

Events.eventName: Platform for Poets: Book Release and Student Reading
Events.Description:
Check out the original work resulting from the fall workshops with prominent poets Claudia rankine and Craig Sworkin. Watch your copy of Dworkin's an Attempt at Exhausting a Space in Williamstown be made in real teime, and pick up your copy of the multi-authored publication, Race in the Life of the Mind. Students will read from their work inspired by Ranking and what she calls the Racial Imaginary, an inquiry into the ways race is created and experienced.
Put on by Publication Studio

Events.eventName: Curator's Insights: Imagining the Trojan War
Events.Description: For the ancient Greeks, the illiad was both entertainment and a record of their past. Trace homer's epic poem across history through ancient and modern works of art by walking through the exhibition with curator Ben rubin, Assistant Professor of Classics

Smithsonian fellow Nina Schleif and Warhol biographyer Blake gopnik explroe Warhol's career as a commercial artist in New York in the 1950s. They will highlight recent discoveries made in their research about his experimental early work. Followed by drinks and mingling

Events.eventName: Curator's Insights: Warhol by the Book
Events.Description: Warhol by the Book is the first US exhibition to focus on Warhol's book work. Walk through the show of more than 500 objects including unique and unpublished materials with Kathryn Price, WCMA's curator of collections.

Celebrate Warhol's birthday with a distinguished bibliophile. Book dealer Andreas Brown and Kathryn Price, WCMA's curator of collections, consider the legacy of Warhol's book work, the lure and collectability of books, the book as art object, and Brown's experiences running a bookshop. 
Followed by cake and a toast.

Susan Rossi-Wilcox, culinary historian, and Darra Boldstein, Professor of Russian and founding editor of Gastronomica: The Journal of Food and Culture, read between the lines of illustrated recipes with a look at a mid-century culture clash.
Wild Raspberries, the cookbook Warhol produced with socialite suzie Frankfurt, serves up satire as it mocks the post-war desire to cultivate a European lifestyle and aesthetic through food.
Drinks and mingling to follow

Lucy Mulroney, Interim Senior Director and curator of Speical Collections at Syracuse University Libraries, and Christopher Cerf, auth, composer, producer, and former Warhol collaborator, share stories from the publishing world about Warhol, who infiltrarted mainstream channels with his counterculture spirit to co-opt its rigid structures, producing books like his Index (Book), a pop-up "children book for hipsters".
Followed by drinks and mingling

Events.eventName: Opening of Warhol by the Book
Events.Description: You are invited to celebrate the opening. A conversation on Warhol & the Stuff of Books follwed by drinks, food, and mingling

Williams Professor c. Ondine Chavoya and NYU Professor Thomas Crow discuss the rise of Pop Art and Warhol's place at its center. They'll share views on 1960s counterculture, the folk revival, Woody Guthrie, the Factory, the Velvet Underground, and more.
Followed by drinks and mingling

Events.Description: WALLS PICK UP DAY
Drop in 6:30-8 pm to chat with students and WCMA staff about how the WALLS collection has evolved. Coffee and cookies provided.

This fall we've temporarily converted a gallery into a workspace. The Henry Luce Foundation generously funded the digitization of over 2,000 American artworks in our collectionl Visit with WCMA staff and learn about their findings.
For spring proposals, contact Liz Gallerani, Curator of Mellon Academic Programs at egallera@williams.edu

Co-presented by the Art Department and the Lecture Committee in partnership with WCMA. Jack Whitten (b. 1939) began his earliest experiments in painting during the 1960s by creating dynamic works inspired by Abstract Expressionism. His work of this period manifests emotionally complex meditations on sociopolitical events that shpaed his own understanding of life: Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.'s legacy, the Civil Rights movement, and the Vietnam War among them. A retrospective on Whitten's 50-year long career is currently on view at the Walker Art Center in minneapolis, MN.

Events.eventName: The Field is the World, program, summer 18
Events.Description:
Reunion program

In August 1986, a box was discovered in the basement of a dorm at Williams College. In it were 64 objects that had been collected a century and a half earlier for the Lyceum of Natural History, a student-run museum on campus from 1835-1909. Among the objects was a Hawaiian kupe’e, or ankle rattle made of dog teeth. The kupe’e inspired a two-part exhibition that surfaces the complex and under-known historical relationship between Williams College and the kingdom of Hawai’i, from the founding of the missionary movement in 1806, to the overthrow of the Hawaiian government in 1893. Drawing on various campus collections and rich archival holdings, the exhibition frames questions about visible and invisible institutional histories, histories of pedagogy and of museum practice, and the impulse to collect and its relationship to agency in the making of histories. Drawing on various campus collections, the exhibition frames questions about visible and invisible institutional histories, museum practice, and the impulse to collect.
Join museum staff to intimately explore these objects behind the scenes, and learn more about this project in process.
This program has capacity for 30 participants.

I'm hoping that the project might be able to incorporate a work or two from WCMA once I get further into the planning. But for now, it would be wonderful to see the following works as I formulate my ideas."

Events.eventName: [We Will] Open With You: General Sisters
Events.Description: The Pittsburgh based art collective General Sisters initiate an exchange of perspectives and nourishment at WCMA with this celebratory community workshop and conversation series. Rather than host a conventional opening event tied to a specific exhibition, General Sisters will invite the museum to open itself—over and over and over again throughout the year.. (We Will) Open With You is a collaboration with General Sisters, students in the Contemporary Curatorial Workshop of the Williams Graduate Program in the History of Art, and Assistant Professor of Art Pallavi Sen. This project extends General Sisters’ neighborhood practice of opening a General Store in North Braddock, Pennsylvania to the Williams College Museum of Art.

Events.eventName: Mirrored Interiors: You Were My First Boyfriend (Images Cinema)
Events.Description:
A public screening of Cecilia Aldarondo’s film You Were My First Boyfriend will be held as part of her solo exhibition Mirrored Interiors. The film will be shown at 6:30 p.m. at Images Cinema, followed by a Q&A with Aldarondo and Sally Berger, film and media arts curator, writer, and teacher. A reception will precede the screening from 5 p.m. at WCMA. Both events are free and open to the public.

What if you could rewrite your adolescence? In this high school reunion movie turned inside out, Aldarondo embarks on a fantastical quest to reconcile her tortured teen years. She “goes back” in more ways than one, tracking down old foes and friends while also reenacting visceral memories of youthful humiliation and desire. Oscillating between present and past, hallucination and reality, You Were My First Boyfriend is a hybrid documentary that explores the power of adolescent fantasy, the subtle violence of cultural assimilation, and the fun house mirror of time’s passage. Perhaps we will all learn something about growing older and making peace with what haunts us.

Events.eventName: Mirrored Interiors: Landfall + opening short Picket Line (WCMA auditorium)
Events.Description:
Screening of Cecilia Aldarondo’s short film Picket Line (2017) and feature film Landfall (2020) will be held as part of her solo exhibition Mirrored Interiors will be held at WCMA from 4 to 6 p.m. in L231.

One week before Donald Trump was elected, 700 workers—many of whom were Trump supporters—walked out of the Momentive chemical plant in Waterford, N.Y., sparking a 105-day strike. In the wake of his win, the striking workers reflect on the election and Trump’s advocacy for union-busting legislation in the short film Picket Line.

Through shard-like glimpses of everyday life in post-Hurricane María Puerto Rico, Landfall is a cautionary tale for our times. Set against the backdrop of protests that toppled the U.S. colony’s governor in 2019, the film offers a prismatic portrait of collective trauma and resistance. While the devastation of María attracted a great deal of media coverage, the world has paid far less attention to the storm that preceded it: a $72 billion debt crisis crippling Puerto Rico well before the winds and waters hit. Landfall examines the kinship of these two storms—one environmental, the other economic—juxtaposing competing utopian visions of recovery. Featuring intimate encounters with Puerto Ricans as well as the newcomers flooding the island, Landfall reflects on a question of contemporary global relevance: when the world falls apart, who do we become?

This screening of these two films will be repeated on Tuesday, April 18.

Events.eventName: Mirrored Interiors: Memories of a Penitent Heart (WCMA auditorium)
Events.Description:
Screening of Cecilia Aldarondo’s feature film Memories of a Penitent Heart (2016) will be held as part of her solo exhibition Mirrored Interiors will be held at WCMA from 4 to 6 p.m. in L231.

Combining a wealth of recently discovered home movies, video, and written documents with artfully shot contemporary interviews and vérité footage, Memories of a Penitent Heart is a documentary that cracks open a Pandora’s box of unresolved family drama. Originating from filmmaker Cecilia Aldarondo’s suspicion that there was something ugly in her family’s past, the film charts her excavation of the buried family conflict around her uncle Miguel’s death, and her search for Miguel’s partner Robert a generation later. After two years of dead ends, Robert turns up: but he’s not the same man. He’s reinvented himself as Father Aquin, a Franciscan monk with twenty-five years of pent-up grief and bitterness. For the first time, a member of Miguel’s family wants to hear Aquin’s side of the story—but is it too little, too late? A story about the mistakes of the past and the second chances of the present, Memories of a Penitent Heart is a cautionary tale about the unresolved conflicts wrought by AIDS, and a nuanced exploration of how faith is used and abused in times of crisis.

The screening of this film will be repeated on Friday, April 21.
